intro: Isoglossa lactea subsp. lactea, commonly known as the milkweed plant, is a herbaceous perennial species native to parts of Europe and Asia. It belongs to the family Apocynaceae and is characterized by its opposite, elliptical leaves and clusters of small, white to pinkish flowers. The plant produces a milky sap that contains toxic compounds, which deter herbivores. It thrives in moist, well-drained soils and is often found in woodland or streamside habitats. Its flowers attract pollinators such as bees and butterflies, contributing to local biodiversity.
